hints_html: Find the steady states of this differential equation. Are steady states actually reached in finite time?
hints_latex:
Find the steady states of this differential equation. Are steady states
actually reached in finite time?
hints_raw: Find the steady states of this differential equation. Are steady states actually reached in finite time?
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
We want to find the steady states of this differential equations. To do so, set \(\frac{dm}{dt} = 0\), i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} 16m\left(1 - \frac{m}{4}\right) -12 = 0\end{aligned}\]

Simplifying yields

\[\begin{aligned} 16m - 4m^{2} -12 = 0\end{aligned}\]

and once more

\[\begin{aligned} m^{2}-4m +3 = 0\end{aligned}\]

Factoring yields

\[\begin{aligned} (m-3)(m-1) = 0\end{aligned}\]

and so the steady states are given by \(m = 1\) and \(m = 3\). It is quickly checked, e.g. by plugging in \(m = 0\), \(m = 2\), and \(m = 4\), that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dm}{dt} = \left\{\begin{array}{rl} \text{negative }& \text{if } m < 1 \text{ or } m > 3, \\ 0 & \text{if } m = 1 \text{ or } m = 3, \\ \text{positive }& \text{if } 1 < m < 3. \end{array}\right.\end{aligned}\]

At time \(t = 0\) we have \(m(0) = 2\). Hence, despite the fishing, the population of fish will grow initially. But the growth will slow down as the population size approaches the steady state value \(m = 3\). A steady state can never be reached in finite time, hence the answer is No, the fish population will never equal 3 million.
sols_raw:
We want to find the steady states of this differential equations. To do so, set <math> \frac{dm}{dt} = 0</math>, i.e.

:<math> 16m\left(1 - \frac{m}{4}\right) -12 = 0 </math>

Simplifying yields

:<math> 16m - 4m^{2} -12 = 0 </math>

and once more

:<math> m^{2}-4m +3 = 0 </math>

Factoring yields

:<math> (m-3)(m-1) = 0 </math>

and so the steady states are given by <math>m = 1</math> and <math>m = 3</math>. It is quickly checked, e.g. by plugging in <math>m = 0</math>, <math>m = 2</math>, and <math>m = 4</math>, that

:<math> \frac{dm}{dt} = \left\{\begin{array}{rl}
\text{negative }& \text{if } m < 1 \text{ or } m > 3, \\
0 & \text{if  } m = 1 \text{ or } m = 3, \\
\text{positive }& \text{if } 1 < m < 3.
\end{array}\right.
</math>

At time <math>t = 0</math> we have <math>m(0) = 2</math>. Hence, despite the fishing, the population of fish will grow initially. But the growth will slow down as the population size approaches the steady state value <math>m = 3</math>. A steady state can never be reached in finite time, hence the answer is '''No''', the fish population will never equal 3 million.


[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2007_Question_6_(b)_log_growth.png|300px|frame|center|Caption: We plot the rate of change <math>dm/dt</math> (<math>y</math>-axis) as function of population size <math>m</math> (<math>x</math>-axis).]]
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

The population of fish in a lake is m million, where \(m = m(t)\) varies with time t measured in years. The number of fish is currently 2 million.

Suppose instead that (because of fishing by humans) m satisfies

\(\frac{dm}{dt} = 16m\left(1-\frac{m}{4} \right) - 12\)

Will the fish population ever equal 3 million? You must give justification for your answer.
statement_latex:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

The population of fish in a lake is \emph{m} million, where $m = m(t)$
varies with time \emph{t} measured in years. The number of fish is
currently 2 million.

Suppose instead that (because of fishing by humans) \emph{m} satisfies

$\frac{dm}{dt} = 16m\left(1-\frac{m}{4} \right) - 12$

Will the fish population ever equal 3 million? You must give
justification for your answer.
statement_raw:
<b> Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required. </b>

The population of fish in a lake is ''m'' million, where <math> m = m(t) </math> varies with time ''t'' measured in years. The number of fish is currently 2 million.

Suppose instead that (because of fishing by humans) ''m'' satisfies

<math>
\frac{dm}{dt} = 16m\left(1-\frac{m}{4} \right) - 12
</math>

Will the fish population ever equal 3 million? You must give justification for your answer.
